The opportvnitie. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1640. Date first performed: 1634.

Bibliographic details for the Source Text James Shirley, 1596-1666 (1596-1666) The Opportvnitie, A Comedy. As it was presented by her Majesties Servants, at the private House in Drury Lane. Written by Iames Shirley. London Printed by Thomas Cotes for Andrew Crooke, and Will. Cooke [etc.] 1640 [75] p. Preliminaries and introductory matter omitted.

Front matter
TO MY TRVLY NOBLE, And my ever honored Friend, Captaine Richard Owen.
The Actors Names.
Aurelio. Pisauro. Pimponio. Lucio. Pietro. Julio. Mercutio. Dutchesse and Ladies. Ferrara. Vrsini. Cornelia. Melinda. Laura. Borgia. Ascanio a Boy. Asca. Grutty.

editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Aurelio Borgia Cornelia Dutchess Pietro Ferrara Grutty Laura Pimponio Julio Melinda Lucio Mercutio Ursini Ascanio Pisauro Servant1 Servant2 Combined Voice

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.stage:
Main text
Act I.
Scene I.
Enter Aurelio, Pisauro, and Pimponio.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Expect me an hour hence, my friend and I
Will walk and see the City, make it your
Care to get Supper ready.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: If I do not
I know who is like to fare the worse.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: And be not
Drunk Sirrah at our return.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Yes I do use
To be drunk before you often.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: About your business:
And how dost like the town, and situation.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Trouble me not to answer such dull questions,
I see never a handsome girl yet, not a piece
Of a bona roba; and the Duchess hold
But the complexion of those we have seen,
I will not be corrupted with the palace
To be her bed-fellow.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You will change opinion;
Perhaps we have seen none but the rubbish, yet
There may be beauties signior will tempt
Your most fastidious appetite, I fear
I shall have much ado to stave thee from them,

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: To quit that fear let us leave the City instantly;
The meal will not digest women, I eat in it.
Not stave me from them?
We are for the wars;
This town will turn my blood, I will not give
A Julio for my courage in twelve hours,
Unless they tie their women up.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Thou hast,
A mind to show thou canst be satyr, patience
But till tomorrow and we will hence.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Sir, let my heart present your welcome home,
You have been too long a stranger, I am happy
To embrace you again.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Me, meaning me, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I hope you are not jealous of my friendship,
I thought our familiarity before
The sad misfortune came that made you banish
Yourself from Urbin had possessed you thoroughly,
How firm I dare be to you.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Do you know him?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Dost thou know him? I never saw his eyes before
To my best memory, are you not mistaken.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Perhaps in your affection which no art
Hath ever made me guilty to deserve,
I never did betray my friend to make you
Affect these clouds, but be it so.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: There is
But one half hour added to our ages
Since first we saw the City.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In good time.
I will be bold to acquaint some bawd else
In whom you have more faith.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What Riddle is this.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Is not the Gentleman on the two sides on his wits?
What did he call you.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Nay I know not, he
Said we had been familiar, in his dream sure,
For waking I never saw him.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You should have asked his name.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: To what purpose prithee.
Why does that Gentleman stare upon us so.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Are you returned, this is confidence
You may repent.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Save you signior.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: And you too.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Do you mean both of us?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: One has some need, you are welcome Signior to
Urbin.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Thank you, what is your name I pray.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: If you have forgot mine, I remember Borgia.
A friend of yours, desires but to renew
Acquaintance with ye.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What friend.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: You will hear more.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Jigs, shall I after him and knock
Him over the pate.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: For what.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: For looking on us
So scurvily.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: That may be dangerous,
Did he not name Borgia.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: But whether
He meant himself or you I understand not.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: He might as well have called me Bethlem Gabor ;
Let us walk on still.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Ha Borgia, it is he, my noble friend returned,
Welcome, a thousand welcomes in thy bosom;
Why do you wear this strangeness in your face,
Can a few years render me lost to Borgia.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Sure he does call me Borgia.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Thou wert
Unkind in thy departure, with what devotion
Could I have been a partner in thy travel
And have unequal fortune, being absent
Why was not I summoned to wait upon thee
In any part of the world, but again welcome,
When arrived ye.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I am very likesome body,
They all mistake me thus, we have seen no friends since.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Is this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: One dear in my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I am your servant, thy unexpected sight
Will glad Mercutios heart, your noble father
Who hath long mourned your absence.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Good old man,
He will rejoice to see him here no doubt of it.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Remember my fathers name.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You have lost an Uncle, but all his estate
Your Father is possessed of.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Dead!

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: His age
Was fit for heaven, his wealth is added to
Your fathers to make yours the greater fortune.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Take it upon you.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Pardon noble friend,
I was persuaded time and absence had
Wrought such a change upon my face, that no man
Would know me again, but though I may to some
Appear a stranger, I must stand discovered
To a friends penetrating eye, again
Possessed your faithful servant, what is my name.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Dear Borgia.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Borgia I must remember you.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Shall I wait on you to your father Sir.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What were I best to do.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Your sister is grown a gallant gentlewoman,
The only beauty of Urbin , and waits on
The Duchess, her soft lips will seal your welcome.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: A handsome gentlewoman, go.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: He does but jest, they are all witches here.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: No more jeers.
Go or be lame for ever.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Is she grown
Worthy that hour you express, and has
The Duchess taken her to grace.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: It is more than whispered,
The favourite loves her.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Who.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He that was cause
Of your remove Ursini.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Cry you mercy,
I know him well enough; but does he love her?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: It is rumoured so in the court.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You will be tripping,
Your own heels up.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I hope my sisters honest.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Who Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Remember that name too.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Let me alone
To remember her, Cornelia for more
Security, I will put her in my table book.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: There is no Lady in the preserves
A clearer fame, as modest as she is fair,
And so ingenious.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I would excuse
Her modesty, but she may be converted
In time; though sturdy Oak we know, and so forth

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: You speak a welcome Character.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Your father
It seems his willing ear hath catched the news
Of your arrive.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Kneel down.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: See if he first knows me,
It is a wise father now knows his own child.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My dearest Borgia, comfort of my age.
My joy of soul, a father's prayers and blessing
Make thee a happy man, my eyes must speak
Part of my joy in tears, welcome from Naples.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Your pardon Sir
That thus I steal upon you, I would hope
My sister---

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Cornelia is in health.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And will be a glad soul to embrace her brother

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Your pardon Sir that I seemed strange to you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: It is recompense now that you please to own me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Iulio an honest gentleman, and one
That loves us Borgia.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: I hear my Uncle
Has left us---

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.l: A good estate, there is the less cause
To mourn for him.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: We must all tread that path,
Here is a friend of mine to whose trust and favour
I have been much engaged.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir what I want
In language, I will supply with other welcome,
Please you to honour my poor wife.

sp.speaker: Pis:
sp.l: The service
Of my unworthy life is yours, command it,
I would you had another handsome daughter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I presume you were presented a glad object
To Lucio, your affections grew from children.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: To Lucio we carry but one heart.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Do not forget his name now.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But my son
We dwell too long thus public, let us perfect
Our ceremony at home, Pietro
One of the favourites creatures.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: It is the Duchess,
Command Mercutio you wait upon her
Presently at Court, and bring young Borgia
Along with you to expect her graces pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: We must obey.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: What makes your countenance change Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My fears poor Borgia for thee.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: For me.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: How is that? his fears?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: While my aged arms are in,
A loving contention to embrace thee,
I wish thee from hence this ground betrayed thee,
Embark again, the Seas have used thee kindly,
Trust them again, or any land but this:
This will undo us both, the joy of seeing thee
Made me forget thy danger.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Danger Sir,
What have I done, to call these fears upon you?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Take heed, be wise, I know not what to think of it

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What hast done sayst, nothing to dishonour thee,
Thou killdest him fairly.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Killed I think; you were best
Be Aurelio again, and leave your sister
But I will fish out the circumstance, walk melancholy.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Prithee do.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Although your son has pleased
To call me friend, I find he has reserved
Something he would not credit to my bosom;
I have observed his trouble, but unwilling
By moving questions to renew his sufferings:
If my particular knowledge of his fate
May be no prejudice, though it be without
My verge to serve him, I can willingly
Share in their grief that love him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You speak nobly,
It was his misfortune Sir provoked to kill
A Gentleman, brother to Vrsini, who
Was favourite to the Duke deceased, and now
Graced by the Duchess, by whose power he may
Command him dead, these summons I suspect;
But take my counsel Borgia, and deceive
His expectation of revenge, once more
He bids thee fly; would slay thee in his heart,
Let me run their displeasure.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Not for me Sir,
I am resolved, it is better dye at home,
Than waste my life an exile, I will to Court with you.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You are not mad.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.l: Thou art a fool, cannot I cast
Borgias skin off when I please, I must
See my fair sister at a minute's warning,
Thou art evidence for me; father I wait you,
My sisters there you say, do not doubt me;
At worst, I will have a trick to keep my head on:
Come friend and Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: We attend.

div1.stage:
Exit.
Enter Dutchesse, Ursini, Cornelia, Melinda, Laura.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: You have prevailed Vrsini : yet we thought
Of all men living you would least have been
A suitor for his pardon, but it is signed
He owes you for his life.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Your mercy rather,
I have considered madam I did lose
A brother, whose repair I shall not find
Now in another's blood, the Gentleman
Hath suffered, though not what the Laws determine.
Many years' penance, so severe, perhaps
That he is come by offering himself now
A sacrifice to your justice, to prevent
A death more killing, still to live a stranger
To his own friends and country.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: If your charity
Extend so far, the rest we have dispensed with,
He is returned for certain? he is either
Weary of life, or master of a confidence
That might have been his ruin.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: This will make
Your art of mercy shine the brighter Madam.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It will, but let me ask you good my Lord,
Does this proceed out of a clear forgiveness:
Time I allow may qualify the thought
Of our revenge, and something else of pity
May so take off the roughness of our soul
That we may have a noble charity
To our enemy, but has your end no mixture
Of something else, that may advance a hope
To satisfy desire some other way?
No turn to profit or delight? be plain
For I must know your breast.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: You shall see through me,
I dare not wear a thought less than transparent,
I love his sister Madam, fair Cornelia
With those intents become me, in that flame
I sacrifice all thoughts that wound her brother
And wish no happy satisfaction,
And by that charm of her consent to love
My brother is revived in Borgia.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: You are brief, yet plain; how point Cornelias
Affections.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: I have wooed her but in complement,
And though there may be sons to admit
My services, I find she is all obedience
To her father, whom the apprehension
Of his sons fortune may have indisposed
To a present reconcilement.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: This one act
Will make him kind, and form him to your wishes.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: If they might have the happiness to be
Propounded by your highness to Mercutio,
I prophesy success, pardon great Madam,
If after all your princely favours I
Beg this with many blushes, love is graced
By dwelling on your breath.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Ursini since
The Duke dyed you have found no loss in our
Esteem, to his ashes I have paid that duty
To grace whom he affected, and be confident
We shall not deny this, is he not come yet?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: He will attend your grace---who waits.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Signior Mercutio
Expects your graces pleasure, with him his son
Borgia

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My brother.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Though we pardon him
We must put on a brow of some displeasure
And chide his fault, he may be encouraged else
To a second insolence.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Gently I beseech you,
There may be a punishment within your eye
To kill him, and so make the benefit
Is meant him, of no vertue, or to himself,
Or my design.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: How is the name of gentleman
Dishonoured by such desperate undertakings;
That more than guilty of human blood, do kill
Even Charity.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: They are admitted.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Is that he?
We sent for you Mercutio to tell you
How much you owe to good Ursinis love,
At whose earnest solicit we have signed
Young Borgias pardon, if you examine well;
You will have cause to place him in the first
Rank of your friends.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Shall I believe my eyes,
My understanding? how is Mercutio blest?
Look boy the pardon, heaven reward thy charities;
My Lord for saving one, command the lives
Of all our family, thou soul of honour;
Look Borgia.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: What do you mean
Kneel to the Duchess, and acknowledge.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: A pardon for your life.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I am lost here
Pisauro, an excellent creature.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You will spoil all,
She is yet your sister, I do like her too;
Kneel for your pardon, and you may choose your gallows
In time, would I were hanged on no worse piece
Of temper, how nimbly would I climb the Ladder,
Ha you no sense? humble your knees to thank
Her highness and that gentleman.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Why does
That fellow kneel Ursini.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: It is Signior Borgia,
His heart is full of thanks.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I look not for them,
What do I feel? command him rise.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Dear Madam.
Look calm upon him.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: She will reverse the pardon.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Are you my brother Sir?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: As sure as you are my sister; do you doubt me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: How now Cornelia, pray excuse me brother,
My joy to see you safe doth half transport me.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Mercutio.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I am converted now,
And do believe there are some handsome women;
Young Gentleman, not too much, too much at once,
Remember you are her brother, he is taken.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your grace is pleased to enlarge my happiness;
My daughter is much honoured, but I must
Beseech your Lordship to allow we may
In such a cause as this, enquire her judgment,
And since by the bounty of your highness, I
Have a son now, whose joy may be concerned in it;
I would not willingly conclude her marriage
Without his voice too.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I am confident
To incline his favour, since she has declared
Herself no enemy.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Sir I have a suite to you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You have deserved
My life, which ought to waste itself in service.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I am an honourer of your fair sister,
It rests in you to perfect my ambition.
And make her mine.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How do you mean my Lord.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Now he is put to it, she is Ursinis mistress.
As he is Borgia, he can have no
Pretence to oppose him, if he discover
And be Aurelio again, he destroys all
Hope for himself, for I perceive he is taken with her
I know by the motion of his nose, which pants
Like the Bellows of an Organ.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Sir your fathers
Voice speaks in yours, you now command my destiny
If you will make me happy.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Noble Sir,
I am sorry where such infinite merits plead
I have no power to serve your noble wishes,
And keep the honour of a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Your family I take it can receive
No stain by my alliance.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: It were a blessing.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: How will he come off?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Mistake not I beseech you,
I have already engaged myself to a Gentleman
Of a noble house in Millan , one Arelio
Andreozzi.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: That is himself.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Who on the sight of
Her picture which I gave him, courted me
To woo the substance for him, promising
To follow me in person, being one
To whom I had many obligations
In the Millan Court, I pawned the credit
Of a gentleman, to assist his fair desires,
If in few days he come to Urbin, but
I am confident his young affections
Which had no other life but what a dead
Representation could infuse, will soon
Vanish again, and leave me to be serviceable
In what you will command me, and be sure
I will not rack your patience to much length;
If in few days he appear not, I will think
My promise disobliged, and direct all
My abilities to make your wishes prosper:
It will become my gratitude.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: You speak nobly.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: The pleasures of the Court will so abate
His thoughts this way, that I presume your Lordship
Will soon be master of that amorous province
You aim at, and much honour your poor servants.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Let this confirm I am yours.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: So so, this was indifferently well carried, I was jealous
Of a more lame come off.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Add this one
To your other princely favours Madam, and
Admit this gentleman to kiss your hand.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Without much suite my heart would have conveyed
That to my lip, a very handsome gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What said the Duchess? do not her eyes fix
Upon my brother? how now Cornelia,
I am his sisters sister, yet I had
No acquaintance with this turbulent passions
When I last saw him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What does her highness mean,
She speaks to Ursini, but her eye directs
Some language this way, Borgia dost observe?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And wonder, but I see nothing in her eyes
To be afraid of.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: If the Duchess should be in love with him
Here were a purchase, I do verily
Believe here will be an end of all our wars,
If he have but the grace to march upon
This service and charge home, smiles, smiles upon him
Well Aurelio Andreozzi , it is very possible
You may meet with your match if he mount her,
I will bring a Ladder to his sisters fort
And then the town is our own, she calls him to her.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Cornelia, canst thou interpret this?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Her grace is very pleasant, good good heart
Be patient.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: She plays with him, good, better,
Aye, is your spirit up my nimble Duchess,
Would I had the conjuring of it down, Vrsini
Looks like a whelp had lost his tail already.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.p:
I was jealous she would chide and frown upon him, prayed her be gentle, and look calm, Is it come
To this.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Vrsini , I have thought how to supply
That place of Secretary that is vacant, see
That Borgia be sworn, we apprehend
His fitness.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: Madam.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: I hope this will please you
Vrsini, we can grace whom you present;
He is more gentleman than to forget
How for your sake we honour him; I shall
Betray too much of women, Borgia
Attends us; come Cornelia, Vrsini ,
Mercutio, make the Court not so much stranger.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I will follow: what dost think of this Pisauro.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I think the Duchess loves thee, and make use of it,
Lose no applications, thou art her Secretary,
A degree to more inward endearments,
If she do love thee, and---

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What prithee?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: She knows best
What appetite she has, let me counsel thee,
Be not modest, we are made.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Thy father a Count, thou a Duke, Vrsini
A Coxcomb, I a fine gentleman, and one
That would be glad of the worst of your
New female acquaintances.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: There are no faces here.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Be not you a Tyrant, I will do penance
In a white sheet with thy sister for it.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: No Signior Aurelio come yet? No master to be heard on, he is a fine Gentleman to use his Squire on this fashion; where should he be, he commanded me not to be drunk, he is drunk; and drunk and dead drunk, he would have had the grace to reel home to his lodging before this time of night else: let me see, what if the flesh have led him a-to-side? He is fallen into some brake, some wench has tied him by the legs, and nothing else can excuse him to me; yet now I think on it, he does forget Pimponio , he was not wont to be his own purveyor, my art for the choice of his Pullin, has been allowed if he do get and so forth an excuse for Physic, and come home foundered, the disease was none of my choosing, it came not through my office; stay, what if my Signior be dead? umph? dead? my heart misgives, they may be killed, my master has the spirit of fighting in him, and his companion is the Devil at it, an aglet hole or two in their hearts, and in a strange place, my Seigniors, are never missed, it is so, if he be dead---bring forth the portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Asc.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Pim.

sp.p: Thy father call him hither.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: He is coming Sir, it is very late.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Never too late to tell money, fetch me a brace of jennets I will mount them, a Covey of Courtesans; stay Pimponio, be not mad before thy time, who shall I say I am? a Prince at least, I have it;
Here comes mine Host.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: What would this fellow have, no news of your master?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Speak that word no more on thy allegiance, here go to bed and rise with a clean shirt.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: This is gold, what does the fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: No fellows neither, it is time to show myself, where is thy boy?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Here Signior.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Kneel down and ask me blessing.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: This does look a blessing, shall I ask another?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Ask anything but what I am.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: You are---

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Stay there, it is dangerous to pronounce me yet, I will be still disguised, my men are absent.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Your men.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Thou art wise, thine ear, I am a Prince.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: How Signior.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: The reason of my shape thou shalt know hereafter, thus Jove has been disguised.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Is not your name Pimponio?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p:
It was my pleasure they should call me so, I have not found them trusty;
How fares the Duchess?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: What do I hear?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: This boy shall wait on me, I will have ye all.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Whether?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: What Country shall I choose? to be a Prince of Italy is too well known, Spain stands convenient, and far enough, where I have been too, I will have you all to Spain.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p:
What to do Signior?
For your preferments, when thou hast got a chapman for this tub thou livest in, let me know it.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Boy this a Spanish Prince.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: A Prince of Oranges, he a Spanish Prince?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: They will not travel thither to disprove me, to tell the truth, I suspect my two Grooms have betrayed me; I come hither to be a suitor to your Duchess.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: In these clothes?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: You do not know my plot, these Gentlemen my servants should cunningly have preferred me to be the Duchess Fool.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Her Fool? it is very likely.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: But for a time, there is mystery in that
By this means I resolved to try her nature
And disposition ere I married her,
sp.p: For I can have at this present four Kings daughters, the eldest of them is but seven years old, which shows the parents dote upon me, and would make sure of me betimes.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: I do believe your grace.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Grace, umph, thou must be advanced, let me see, what office, O, thou shalt have a place at my return in the Galleys, dost hear, a yerking preferment.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: And what shall I be

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Thou shalt be---a Picaro , in your language a Page, my chief Picaro ; by degrees you may send for all your generation, I will see them mounted.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Where is Pimponio

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: A pox Pimp you, they are alive again, now am I a dead man.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: There is a certain movable ycleped a Portmanteau.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Would your tongue had been clipped.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Wherein there are some golden friends of ours.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: All your friends are well.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: Let me see their complexions, where are they? look for the Signior your master a month hence?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: His master, do you observe?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Does he not carry it handsomely, he knows not I have discovered myself to you.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: With your pardon Sir, is not this Signior a Prince disguised?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.p: A Prince of Puppets, who Pimponio?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: And you one of his servants, to whom with
Your other fellow called Signior Aurelio,
His person stands discovered, he came hither
To court our Duchess, he has promised us
At his return to Spain to make us Grandees.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Has he betrayed himself, nay then my duty
If please your excellence.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Away, away.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: A Prince cannot be hid though under mountains,
But my dear Prince, the bags must go with me
While you keep state in the Inn.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Who shall maintain.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: If I did think thou wouldst carry it hansomly---
Well, I will excuse thee to thy master, here
When thou hast domineered away this bag
Thou mayst hear more; keep thine own counsel, and
Thy master shall not own thee, if thou hast
Any vagary, drink, and indulge thy Genius ;
I will see thee again before thy reign be out,
No words but be a prince, and scorn to know us
And so I take leave of your excellence.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I shall not know myself, am not I a Prince
Indeed, that have been long concealed? this is a bag
And full of golden friends, umph, however I will
Spend it like an Emperor, these are not robes
Fit for a Prince I take it, Grutti, boy
I entertain you both my Groom and Page, and
Say unto you, Snakes go cast your coats,
Here is earnest for new skins, when things are ripe
We will to Court.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.l: What thinks your grace of going to bed

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: I am too sober, let the whole house be drunk first, it will please us well to see the servants gambol, we purpose
sp.l: To be drunk ourselves in state too:
Let me have fifty strumpets.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.l: Fifty trumpets.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Strumpets I say, they will make the greater noise.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: Your grace will be a Hercules.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: I will, and thou shalt be Captain of the Pygmies under me, this room is too narrow, beat down the walls on both sides, advance your lights and call the Country in, if there be a Taylor amongst them he shall first take measure of my highness, for I must not longer walk in Quirpo.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: We attend your excellence.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I am lost in the wonder Iulio.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A strange turn
From that could temper we imagined
In her Highness.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I have heard of charms and philters.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: If travel have these glorious effects
I will abroad too.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: He has a handsome person.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: And discourses grant it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Is master of a noble soul.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Soul, nay let that alone, Ladies do not look
After the soul so much, the body will serve their
Turn, so it be nimble, and at their devotion,
If you observe, he is graced by all the Ladies
As if he were their general minion,
I do not like his sisters eyes upon him,
They whirl too much and seemed to shoot an envy
Upon the Duchess favours.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I am confident
Thou hast no murmur in thy thoughts against him.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I but express my wonder,
In that I think the whole Court had a share:
He knows I love him, it will become his fear
How to secure Ursini.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: He preferred him
First to her highness.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Not with expectation
To be supplanted, I make question
If the humour hold, whether she may not marry him,
That is a round higher than her favourite:
Had hope to climb.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Although I honour Borgia
And wish him heartily advanced, I would not
Kneel to him, my voice is for Ferrara
He is a Prince, I would not for my state
This should break off his treaty.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Thy Ambassador
To his master, he is scarce minded.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Come she cannot,
Fall so low, the passion is too violent
To last---who are these?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: The Ambassador and Ursini, what is the matter?
I fear some discontent.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: My Lord let me
Prevail so far, I hope you imagine I
Am firm to you, I have more cause to be
Impatient, my whole strength at Court is concerned,
But have more noble thoughts than to suspect
You can be slighted, think it is but a dream
Injustice to your cause, and royal master
Put on no face of discontent, return
And see how things will close

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It is an affront
Above satisfaction, but the disgrace
Reflects beyond my person.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Had she studied
Honours to his ambition, it had
Not wronged her prudence, to have shown you more
Respect.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: But I was not considerable;
The young Gentleman had taken up her eyes,
Her tongue, her feet, her understanding too,
I might have withered in my seat, no beam,
No discourse this way, but that once she was pleased
To ask me how I liked the gallants dancing,
I will not disturb her revels.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yet my Lord
Have so much fortitude, it will be a means
If you return, to make her find her error
To your person, were she not my Princess
I should profess myself ashamed, but come
Let me beseech you to go back, leave not
The presence so, for your own honour Sir
Observe a little more, I hope you shall not
Repent my counsel.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I would ye would excuse me,
I shall but vex my eyes.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Expect a change.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You have power with me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: You honour me.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: What will become of this, what think you now?
They do resent it, and for aught I hear
Have little hope to mend it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Can she be
In love so soon, well Borgia, if this
Hold, I will applaud thy fate.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: For after this
Allowance, he will be Duke of Urbin tomorrow,
Give thee joy bully, let me see if he
Turn Prince, it is best for us turn beggars.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Beggars?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Court beggars, He will deny us nothing,
Now for some witty knave to find out suits,
I must keep some in pension for that purpose,
They are profitable vermin,
His companion.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Save you Gentlemen, what do ye mean?
Why stand ye bare?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In being Borgias friend
It will become us.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He knows no title yet,
But chief secretary to her highness, what honours
Are in her breast laid up for him, we know not
He has a mounting fate, and in his we
Pronounce you happy.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: We shall all be Princes
In time; but Gentlemen let us be more familiar
We think so well of things, does he preserve
The Duchess smile, or does she use to make
At some time of the Moon sport with her subjects.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You are wide all the heaven Sir, had you come
A little sooner you had heard discourse.
To clear your doubt, he is here himself.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Pisauro,
What will become of us, it is as thou sayst?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: What prithee?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: The Duchess is mad.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Why she is certainly in love, shat in and see
How I am used, and yet I now come forth
To recover breath, I have danced myself to a jelly,
The Ladies have no mercy; but the Duchess

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: What prithee.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Is as I told thee mad, I prithee counsel me
Although her grace be pleased to show me favours
It were boldness to believe, and thank her.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: How?
I hope thou art not mad.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I know not whether
The fit will last, I may hold some proportion
With Cornelia, my supposed sister, she
Poor wretch does cast such speaking eyes upon me
As she were Jealous of the Duchess too,
And wrings me by the hand when I dance with her.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: The Duchess Sir calls for you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I attend;
What were I best to do?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Dost make a question
Lose not the fortune that is presented in
The Duchess love, thy stars ordained thee for her;
I will make a shift with Cornelia, look high
And prosper, when thou art a Duke, I say no more

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What shall us do with Pimponio? that fool
May betray all.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: He is a Prince before you
I have made him sure, and swollen him into a pride,
He shall not know you, but of that hereafter,
Away and please the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your graces pardon?

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: It is late, good night my Lord Ambassador.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It is well I am bid goodnight, yet all my hopes
Vanish in mists, what think you now cousin?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I know not what to think, let me wait on you
To your lodgings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: They join to the Court.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: It is the less service.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Tomorrow morning if I may be honoured
With your presence, I will impart a secret to yon,
And be happy in your Counsel.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I obey
Any commands.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: For this time give me pardon, goodnight my Lord.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: A happy night to your Lordship,
After so many years spent in the Court,
I am to learn the trick of it, these are actions
Gainst my first rules, I am ignorant
Of this new Court philosophy, what should
The Duchess mean, so prodigal of her graces
To one she scarce remembers, with such open
Neglect to the Dukes' Ambassador? I was careful
She would not use him kindly enough, wert not
Affection to his sister, lies up my
Revenge, I would drop it on his heart, but I
Must work with art, and by a Counter magic
Dissolve his spell, or form him to my purpose.
You have been waiting on the Duchess Ladies?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: She dismissed us.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: With what circumstance?
Is she still pleasant?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Strangely altered
Since young Borgia took his leave and melancholy:
Well, I suspect---

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: What Madam?

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Tonight, for dreaming of the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: He is gone then?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Yes, we saw his departure my Lord,
He kissed us both, but we put forward first,
He is the handsomest Gentleman; do you think
He wears his own hair?

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: I was about
To ask him once, but thought he was modest
And would have blushed, I would I had his picture.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: His substance Madam, but take heed, the Duchess
Must have no rival, how do you affect his talk?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: That was not my part to observe, we did divide
Our Provinces, each Lady took a member
To examine, when we have conferred our notes
I will tell ye what the body of Ladies think on him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: Nay we will take him a pieces ere we have done.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: And who shall set him together again? my Ladies
I wait on you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Your Lordship will too much honour us.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: It is the way to my own lodging.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: If it were not the way my Lord, your Lordship
Could not be destitute of a lodging at Court.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Your Charity would relieve me, use my service.

div1.stage:
Exit.
Enter Ferrara and Pietro with a light.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: There is no such affliction to the soul
As that which should preserve it, love, a passion
That with consent betrays our understanding,
And leaves man but a heap of flame and ruins;
I was safe till I had seen her, busy fame
Took but possession of my ear, my own
Rashness and vanity engaged my person
To see what was commended, and I suffer for it,
Leave me.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: It is dark my Lord.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thou liest, it is light
And by these fires I see too much, away,
I shall soon reach my lodgings, night and I
Shall agree well together, if my stay
Be long, remember that you left me under
The palace windows, leave to be officious
And obey me---till this night she gave me fair
Respect, and seemed to allow the loving treaty,
I was dull not to uncloud me all this while
The knowledge of my person had engaged her
Beside my act of love, and so much confidence
Past all retreat, and yet she is a woman,
Whose nature is unsteady as the waves,
Upon which foolish man runs desperate
To me a ruin.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: Fortune thou smilest too much, I shall suspect
Thy giddiness, take eyes to thee and see
To what a flattering height thou hast exalted
A credulous man.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What voice is that, it had
A sound of melancholy, darkness secure me.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: But why make I ridiculous application
To fortune? love is only active here;
The tyrant love, more blind than chance, I am
Full of distraction, there is a labyrinth
Within, and more I tread, the more I am lost
Betwixt the Duchess and Cornelia
My soul divides, I must not be a fool,
And for the fable of amorous love
Leave state that courts me with a glorious title,
And yet Cornelia is fury, and looks
Withal the charms of love upon her brow,
What will she do when she believes I am
No brother?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It is the new ague Borgia
That shakes the court, how confidently he talks
To himself, a light strikes from the Duchess window
And music; I will observe, the gallant may
Have some appointment.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Alas poor lovesick Lady, what if I
Attempted farther, the excuse will fall
More easy on a stranger, Lady, hist.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Who is that?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: One that does wish the happiness
To see your face, you have blest my ears already.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: My name is Borgia, if you be
A fair one of the court, time is not old
Since I was a guest there.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: It is he, I will not lose
This opportunity, Sir your boldness
Speaks you a stranger, and in part excuses
You are alone.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I am.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I expect not
Upon so small acquaintance you should know
My voice again, I am the Duchess Sir.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your graces humble creature, may I hope
You will pardon this attempt.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Upon condition
You will forget the freedom of our nature
And not grow insolent upon our favours,
We were late pleased to show you, it was not love
But mirth, we meant our court the wantonness
Of revelling nights, which we upon retirements
Know how to check and punish too in men,
That dare licentiously apply to our
Dishonour: if your service in that place
Of secretary we have named you for
Be diligent and faithful, we repent not
That choice, but on your life feed no ambition
Higher, it will be a degree next treason
To us, and the honour of Ferrara's Duke,
With whom because you are our secretary
We let you know our thoughts are fixed to marry,

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What blessing hath my ear took in? she is
Resolved to my desires.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Are you gone Sir?
Sleep wisely if you can, we shall expect
Your attendance in the morning, but no thought
On forfeit of your life beyond what is duty.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I have enough tomorrow I resolve
To be myself, and with a state becoming
Ferraras Duke, challenge this happiness,
Forgive dear Princess I suspected thee.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The Duchess she will spoil all.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I heard your voice more loud than usual,
Whom spake you to?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Here is nobody and please your grace.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: You hold some dialogue at the window then,
I will know.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My brother Borgia Madam.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Borgia , leave us.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I hope he is gone.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I must confess you are my Princess Madam,
To whose least command I owe my blood and fortune.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: He speaks to me, how does he know I am here?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And do not think I can be lost so much
In duty to interpret there was anything
In me, that could deserve more than your pastime;
And let me fall and dye beneath your anger,
When I transgress so far, as to forget
My humble fate which only can be blest
With my obedience to you, I had not
One saucy application of your favours,
My heart shall bleed to death ere it shall find
One thought of so much impudence.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: How is this?
Since Cornelia has usurped my name
And frighted him, what should make her officious
He is her brother, I must hear no more
Of this---you are mistaken all this while,
I am Cornelia your sister.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Is the Duchess gone?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: You well distinguish voices, yet she is gone.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: My joy of soul, dearest Cornelia.
It is she that I must trust to.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Is it even so?
Dear brother, leaving all your studied complements
I do not like your dilatory reasons
To Ursini , I may hear you as a brother,
But must not trouble you to choose my husband;
It is the Duchess pleasure, I should marry
Ursini, an advancement more than I
Can hope, from your election of a stranger
And set your heart at rest, however I seemed
Inclining, destiny is not more fixed,
Than the affection I owe Ursini ,
Him I resolve to marry, and before
The next days light is wasted.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I am undone
On both sides, hear me yet but speak.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What would you say brother?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I am not thy brother.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: How, not Borgia.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Not Borgia, the whole town is mistaken
My name is Aurelio Andreozzi ,
I was born in Millan, with my friend designed
To see some service in the German wars;
At the first sight I must confess I loved thee:
To enjoy thy conversation more freely,
I was content to seem what men would call me

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: You tell me wonders.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I can give thee proof,
But to no purpose now, and tell thee too
Enough to make thee think I may be worthy,
But since it is so, I am glad you have discovered
Your resolution so soon, good night to ye,
I will make no noise tomorrow, when I take
My journey.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Stay, he must not be so lost,
This is a strange discovery, if you can
Bring testimony that you are not Borgia ,
You shall not Sir repent your coming hither,
Nor yet despair of any noble ways
That may reward your good opinion,
It is late; a lovers dream charm all your senses,
And waking find your wishes, if you please
Until I ask a further satisfaction,
Be still concealed.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: There may be hope, although
My first love I confess reflect on this,
The Duchess yet, had not been much amiss.

div1.stage:
Actus Tertius.
Enter Grutti and Ascanio.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Why , I shall hardly take thee for my own natural child.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Let me alone with my Don, if I do not fit him, let me never find the way into my own breeches again, I would be loath to die in a wrong case and be mistaken in another world; is the music ready, and the wine father? can the fellows do their dance handsomely, in stead of a mask to entertain his highness, I am sorry my legs are out of tune, I have a great mind to be capering.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: My own wit, my own natural wit to a hair.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Not too much hair of your own, and wit together, father, it is not the fashion: do ye hear, whatsoever I say, be you drunk time enough to justify it, the bills shall be discharged without scrupulous examination, souse in wine and give him Sea room, if his head leak we will pump his breeches, he shall not sink with all his ballast I warrant him.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: A witty crack, and my own boy still.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: Your own boy? take heed what you say, lest you be driven to justify it, you have no mind to wake my mother from her grave, it is enough I ask you blessing, I do long to be metamorphosed, and pursue his princely humour out of breath --- Music, it is well, his grace is upon entrance.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Dispatch boy.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: I know my cue to enter.

div1.stage:
Exit.
Enter Pimponio, like a Spanish Don, and Servants.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: And how, and how do things become? We were in clouds but now.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Your highness is broken out.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Broken out, where?

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Out of the clouds and please you.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: There is no infidel among you then,
You all believe I am a Prince, do ye hear,
At all adventures let it go no further,
There are no traitors I hope amongst ye.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Traitors, we will cut off any man's neck that dares but think so.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Do and I will justify it, hang necks among friends, although I am pleased to reveal the majesty of my person to you, it is not fit everyone should know so much, you are strangers, and therefore I dare trust you, but the Duchess must not hear of it upon your lives; she and I must be better acquainted when I see my time; I will tell you, the toy may take me in the head to look like a fool again, it may, greatness is given to humours, and giddiness will run in a blood, if it do, do not know me.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: For any other than I seem.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: Not a fool.

sp.speaker: Pim.
Gr.
sp.p: Will not your highness have the dance first?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: They will dance the better when they are three quarters drunk.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: We do not observe men of your nation to be so jovial.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Not subjects I grant you that, but we

I will preserve my state, this is a Princely draught---
We drink alone.
so---Why have we not a Concubine?

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Brave Prince, with what a majesty he drinks.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Now let them frisk the dance you have prepared, I am ready to accept it.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: And it shall please your grace,
There is a high German desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: 1. Ser.
sp.p: The high German that was at Court, he is a man of mighty parts and known to all the Princes in Christendom, what comes he for?

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: I fear you are betrayed Sir, and that the Duchess has sent for you.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: For me, I would not come yet.

sp.speaker: 2. Ser.
sp.p: Do not affront him Sir, for your own sake, this high German has beaten all the Fencers in Europe.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Let him beat all the world, what is that to me? shall he make a prize of me?

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: But if he come Ambassador from the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: That is another matter, give me the tother bottle--- Now let all the Cantons of Swiss come.
Which is the high German? let me see him.

sp.speaker: Gr.
sp.p: That Sir.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: He is one of the lowest high Germans that ever I looked upon.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: I kiss thy highness hand.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: And we embrace this lowness: do ye hear Sir, are you a high German?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.p: I was so at the beginning of the wars, what we are beaten to you may discern.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: Are you beaten to that? you will be a very little nation and the wars continue.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: I have a message to deliver you,
The fair Duchess of Urbin , whom I wait on,
Hearing a person of your blood and quality
So meanly lodged, by me desires you would
Accept an entertainment in her Court.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: We give the Duchess thanks, how knew she I was here?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: It was impossible
You should stay undiscovered many hours.
Princes have strange intelligence, and you may
As soon tie up the Sun beams in a net
As keep yourself unknown; for my own part
I am honoured in the embassy, and shall
Be proud to write myself your pensioner
As I am to all the royal blood in Christendom.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: O Pensioner, it is the least honour we intend thee, I am a natural Prince as sure as I live; here wear this gold, there is more to drink our health, we are pleased no man be sober at our return, as he will answer it, you may be all my subjects: if I marry the Duchess I will hang you all.

sp.speaker: Ors.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: In chains of preferment, drink I say, and drink to purpose, what will become of me now? stay, a word with you high German, what will the Duchess do with me do you think?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: It were sin to say she will honour you, for you
Are above all addition but her love;
Your wit, your blood, your person, do not lose
The opportunity, yet I prophesy
You will be affronted.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: No matter, I have been affronted a hundred times, but by whom?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: Questionless by some great ones,
And perhaps beaten.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I have been beaten too upon good occasion,
And will again to save my honour; beaten?
I can take the strappado, beside in this part
I am insensible, a kick is cast away.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: If you be valiant and endure, it will
Engage her love the more, but I know
Your breeding will afford you impudence
To overcome their envies, and secure
This Dukedom to yourself, go on boldly,
My counsel shall attend.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I will go on, and fear no beating, well
I cannot knight thee, yet prove but a witch
I will make thee one of my privy counsellors.

div1.stage:
Exit.
Enter Mercutio, Iulio, and Lucio.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No more, my duty will not let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: How not your duty Sir?

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: You are not angry?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are his friends, I should not else be pleased.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: We have said nothing to afflict you thus,
We did expect this would have made you merry.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A son's preferment was not wont to be
Such discord to a father, a loving father,
For so we took your constitution.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Preferment? it is too poor a word.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You were best tell me too he may be Duke.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: He is in the rode, I know not how he will miss it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: This is three quarters treason, though I love
My son, I must not cherish this ambition.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: But it will be more than three quarters treason
If you presume to check the Duchess pleasure,
And murmur thus if she resolve to marry,
And make your son a Duke, you will not turn rebel.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Defend allegiance, Gentlemen mistake not
Although I love my son, I will not be guilty
Of any thought to cross her, but I should
Be sorry he should cast away himself.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: How do ye mean?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: As men do use when they
Do hang or drown themselves.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Have you sense
And talk thus wildly.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes and understand
The riddles you have told me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Do you count
Your son lost by the Duchess loving him?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Go find your wits again, and use them better,
Can you be so ridiculous to think,
So wise, so modest, so religious
A Lady can forget her state and honour
To place affection on my son.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: There have been
Presidents to make it seem no wonder.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She had better taken his head off, there had ended
My cares, the boy to run mad, and what can follow
Think ye? go to, I will to her highness presently.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: What to do?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: To pray her leave him to a natural death,
And choose some other to undo with pride
Of her large favours; gentlemen examine
But yourselves, could either of you two promise
To keep your wits, if such a grace were offered
To you? would it not tempt you to be mad,
To think of being a Duke? speak honestly,
Is it fit indeed you should be less than mad?
There be some men in the world have lost their senses
When they but showed the Cud of a bare Lordship,
I have known a knighthood has turned some men's wits,
The very noise of the spurs; then do not blame me
If I desire my son sober and sensible,
And now I think on it I will first seek him out.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: I think the old man is mad indeed,
Dear Madam Laura ,

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Sweet Sir I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Then I can walk and wait on you.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You have the same haste too,
Thou art a piece of the Duchess Cabinet,
I must hear some news.

sp.speaker: Me.
sp.l: Alas the Court is barren.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: I know a trick to make thee fruitful yet,
Nay I can mend my pace Lady if you put me to it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Good Sir the reason why you wonder at me
Above all other women, what in me
Appears so full of prodigy.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I will tell you,
You are young and handsome.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Should I grant I were,
This were no miracle.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Withal this youth and handsomness you are a maid
And live at Court too, this I hope is not ordinary.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What wonder will your fancy create next.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You are sound too, or your physiognomy deceives me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The privilege of my brothers friend must not
Engage me to a mockery.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I was
About to say you are patient too, I see
Something would make you angry, but return
To your first temper, and I will soon acquaint you
With all my purpose Lady, to all these
Commendations, which meet not in all women,
You have birth and fortune, and the favour of
The Duchess.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: All these carry no such wonder
If I have understanding.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: No, no, you
Are all the wonder Madam that with these
Advantages a your side to draw up men's
Affections, yet as you despair to have
A Husband to the discredit of your sex,
Who article at twelve to be dissemblers;
You are in love.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: In love, is that a sin?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Nay, nay, you court a Gentleman with eyes
That are not lawful.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: How Sir, be not rude.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I can say more.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Is it your mirth or madness.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: No, no, you are mad, worse, I will prove it,
You dote upon your brother, come it is impious,
Purge, purge betime, your blood is foul, I am plain
There is some of it in your face now that would blush
I see through your hearts, a little more
Had spoiled him quite, he had forgot all laws
Of nature and religion, and been fond
To both your shames; a brother, and a sister
Tempt one another, good heaven where is conscience
And modesty become? preserve yourself
You have yet a good name, keep it and drink Juleps,
You will find the benefit in your veins.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You have
Been very bold upon my constitution.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I know it better than your Doctor, Come
Do not deny it, I make no proclamation;
What is it to me more than my Christian care
You should not hurt your souls, he is my friend
Betray him not, it is no good sisters part
I can assure you, if you be not dull
Or blind with giddy passion, you may see
Another star shoot influence on him;
Be wise and envy not the Duchess favours,
Your vessel may be rigged, and trimmed, and launched
Into a calmer Sea, and return fraught
With lawful prise hereafter, I have stirred her,
But must not be too hasty.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I shall show
Myself too full of guilt.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You are troubled at it,
A sign of grace; how ever you think of me
Now in the heat of Counsel I am your friend,
You will find it so, I kiss your hand, farewell.
Do ye hear? but two words more, if you do find
As being acquainted best with your own body,
No disposition to hold out longer,
I have that will cure you, and I will justify it
Before the colledge---Take me,
Do ye mark, that does it, I kiss your hand,
Again farewell, and have a conscience,
I will tell you more next time, this way may work.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: This Gentleman's discourse though somewhat wild
And without method shakes me, I am lost
If I obey, I know not what within me
Too Prompts me to a love so irreligious;
He is my brother, holy thoughts possess me,
And when a furious passion seeks to invade
My will, destroy it heaven---he is here I dare
Not stay to tempt my frailty, let them move
With joy, I am not in my sphere of love.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: But tell me signior, nay we are pleased
You should be free, upon what confidence
Knowing your guilt, and danger to reward it
Durst you return to Urbin.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I was more fortunate
Than I have reason for, and yet my country
And friends were precious madam, nor could life
In such a wilderness abroad, where none
Durst own me, be a benefit; there was
A blessing in my fate to meet your mercy
That gave me boldness.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Cunningly dissembled,
You met no Lady then in all your travel,
I mean none whom you called mistress, with
Her loving magic to lay charms upon you
And forced your stay.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: None Madam, I was not
Worth any Ladies thought, none were so lost
To their own Judgments to imagine me
More than a walking shadow, or if any
Had cherished better thought of me a stranger,
They quickly found, they had not placed it right,
On so much barrenness which left their charity
To pay itself.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: You do not promise such
A hard and horrid composition,
But love may find a shift to enter more
Than skin deep in your bosom, but perhaps
You left your heart at home, and could not then
Dispense with new engagements, it was so,
And for her sake you willingly forgot
Your danger to return, nay be not troubled,
Confession will not injure you, I like
You should prefer the beauties of your country.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: It Cannot be thought flattery, if I
Acknowledge with the narrowest observation
My eyes could take, no place hath been more fruitful
In beauty than your own, and it doth hold
Proportion with your excellence, all should
Be fair and imitate your first example.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I see you can be when you list a Courtier,
But this confirms your love is planted here;
And since we are fallen by accident upon
This subject, we will pursue it a little further;
Come I must know your Mistress, do not doubt
I shall disturb the progress of your loves.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: What answer shall I frame, things are not ripe
Yet for discovery, so please your highness
You would be modest, and excuse, be wiser
And apprehend my meaning to advance
Your wishes, it is within my power to effect
As much as your ambition can aim at:
Who is it if her heart be stubborn, we
Can make it soft; if great above your fortune,
We can raise you to her equality,
Or bring her down to your level, since we have promised
In hope not to repent: either declare
The mistress of your thoughts, and find them prosper,
We are not used to express such bounteous language,
But be she proudest, greatest in our Duchy,
Without all limitation, she shall carry
No birth or state here, to despise the service
You fairly mean her: if we fail in this,
We will not think our strength worth the preserving

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: If I have any wit.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Madam the Duke.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What Duke?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The Duke of Ferrara with a glorious train
Is come to Court, and as the loud voice is
Given out by himself, to claim you for his wife,
For which he has your promise.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: How our promise?
Can Princes be so insolent, beshrew
His haste, but we shall lose much of our honour
To give no ceremony to his person?
How ever our thoughts point, we will entertain him
And dress our face in smiles.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: His looks renew
My sufferings, I have not power to manage
My wild affection, my heart will not
Be denied but by a secret destiny.
---Brother.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Ha, Cornelia
I hope you are not courting Borgia ,
He is your brother, know your place within
Our train.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She is jealous, jealous, stars I thank you,
It is clear as light she does affect me now:
Did she not put me to it, to name my mistress,
Yet in a shadow pointed at herself?
Be she the proudest, greatest in our Duchy
Without all limitation, I marked that
And had my sense---if great above your fortune
We can raise you to her equality:
Fine morals, poor Cornelia loves me too,
But I must give her no encouragement:
Her grace is much the better woman---ha.

div1.stage:
Loud Musicke.
A passage over the Stage, Duke, Dutchesse, Ursini, Iulio, Lucio, Pietro, Ladies.

sp.l: She appeared discontent when first Cornelia
Brought her the news, yet they march lovingly
Together, but that ceremony must
Be allowed at Court, where shift of face and tongue
Are wisely to be practiz'd---my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Your servant Borgia.
It is her graces pleasure every gentleman
That has relation to the Duke, taste all
The bounties of her Court.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How is this?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: None dare
To affront a Groom on forfeit of his place,
Let all the offices of entertainment
Be free and open.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I shall signify
These her commands.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: And they that of her own
Court are ambitious to express their duties
Let it appear in keeping this day solemn
To wine and mirth, that every brow may speak
A joy and welcome to the Duke.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I shall.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Here is like to be a triumph, with your Lordships
Pardon; was that the Duke of Ferrara,

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yes of Urbin shortly, when their marriage
Is perfect, every subjects heart prays for it,
And sent their acclamations to heaven
To see her highness lovingly salute him,
He is a brave Prince.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A good round gentleman,
He did not fly hither; I heard talk of an
Ambassador.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: A cloud for his own person
Till his affairs came to maturity,
He stood concealed to the Duchess, but last night
He gained her princely word to marry him,
And is this morning bright in his own glories.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Last night.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I will build more faith upon his honour
Fast as a contract.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To what painted Paradise
Would she have led me? would I had my sister now.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: With this joy
I had forgot my own, Borgia; Brother
Let not the sound be unwelcome, it is the Dutchesses
Pleasure to honour her unworthy creature
Ursini, by appointment of our marriage
To Wait on hers.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What marriage?

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: With your sister,
I will not suspect your love, since fair Cornelia
Is not displeased to be directed by
Her highness, and be confident my love
Shall make the memory of it welcome to you;
You will excuse me if I take my leave,
These hours are full of business, and I have
Many commands upon me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: In good time,
I am in a good state again, I was an ass
To think the Duchess meant me anything
But mockery, she told me so before
To make more sport, I have lost my sister too,
She is for Ursinis carving, I could curse
Myself to Millan , but it is not impossible
I may retrieve Cornelia , by giving her
A timely satisfaction, I am not
Her brother Borgia :
There is all the hope is left, I shall be loath
To hunt two hares, and after lose them both.

div1.stage:
Actus Quartus.
Enter Mercutio and Borgia at severall dores.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Son you are well met.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your pleasure Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No great pleasure, I am almost hoarse with
Enquiring for you, I must ask you a question,
First let me examine your countenance.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your meaning Sir?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I have no skill in Metaposcopy,
Do ye know me?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I am not discovered sure,
What crotchet is this?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He is proud, he will not know me:
It is so, he is lost, he is undone, nay, nay,
It will become me to stand bare to you Sir,
And teach my hams the officious cringe; be covered.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I know not how to interpret Sir your language;
Yet I would hope you mock me not, although
It was the Duchess pleasure to create
Mirth from this barren heap, and counterfeit
Favours to try my duty, join not you
With others to enlarge my scorn, I am not
So tame of soul, but I have sense of all
Their jeers.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Their Jeers? whom do you point upon?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I dare not name the Duchess; I am all
Obedience to her person, yet she might
Have placed her giddy humour somewhere else
It swells not me with expectation,
I was not made for state.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do not you then
Think to be Duke.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Should any but yourself
Name such a title to me, I should answer
His question with a frown, and something else
To wait upon it, though I engaged my life
To a fresh danger, but I am instructed
By nature and religion to be calm
At what you say.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: On this condition
I will give thee leave to beat me, it was my fear
Thou hadst an easy faith, and wert transported
Indeed out of thy wits, but since I see
Thou art not mad, I will commend a wife to thee.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: To me, I thank you Sir, not yet,
I shall be mad indeed then, I will marry
None but my sister, take my word.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Thy sister?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I cannot rail upon the Duchess safely;
A wife, my mother is dead.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Thou wouldst not have her?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I think you would not have her out of heaven.
It were little Charity, and the whole sex
Were in a dead sleep were it not sin to wake them;
A wife, I will seek my sister.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Stay and take
My keys, this opens to my gold, go home
And take out ten bags.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What to do Sir?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: To spend them, all is, thine own, leave something for
Cornelia, because perhaps she will marry,
And I am satisfied, a prudent boy,
How am I bound to heaven that he is not proud,
Nor taken in the subtle toils of women?
He will never marry, how shall I consume
My estate? Dost hear, a little portion
Will serve Ursini with thy sister.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Must
He marry her?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I let him, we shall please
The Duchess too, and when she is disposed,
The rest is ours to revel with.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I will think on it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Did you not meet my son?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Yes somewhat melancholy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are deceived, he is choleric, and let
Me advise you gentlemen, although I know
He loves you, do not mock him, he is no fool;
No bladder to be swollen with breath of praise
And Ladies Jigs, he is sensible he is,
And will not be the hateful stock of pastime
To Grooms and Pages.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: What do you mean my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Call him not Duke, I counsel you.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: We do not.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nor do ye not think it possible it may be.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Have patience, and we do not, we have altered
Our opinions, and are clear of your side now.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: As the wheels move we do think nothing less,
Your son shall not be Duke, there is no fear of it
Whilst Ferrara lives.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He shall not.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: So we say, sleep quietly.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He shall not, very peremptory,
You are no Oracles, would I were Duchess
For half an hour, he should be Duke, do ye hear now;
No matter who repented: I thought you
Had been his friend, he shall not be a Duke?
However I thought on it, it becomes not you
To circumscribe his fortune, he can number
Descents of noble blood, and had his breeding;
Has none of the worst faces, heads, nor hearts,
However you value him and discharge your bolts
At random thus, he shall not.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Hear us Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He shall not be a Duke.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Did not I say he was mad?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: That was dissembled,
He has cause now to see a turn in the stream,
And Ferrara only hopeful with the Duchess,
What thing is that?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Is he so confident?

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: He will lay about like a Prince, do ye think
We may present him safely? if you say
The word I will wind him up to an Emperor.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Keep thy shape boy, we would not lose the sport,
And happily I will acquaint these gentlemen.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: If I
Should be whipped heartily for my conceit,
The little high German would not take it kindly,
It may be the court largesse; but no matter,
I have some gold and dare venture the last
At any time for coin of this complexion.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Are you in earnest.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: It will be excellent,
And please her highness, she has commanded
All liberty of mirth, I will undertake
To prepare her.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: About it then, I will have
My part in the interlude, lose no time boy,
Thou shalt be Prince of Pigmyland for this:
The Duchess, I will withdraw.

div1.stage: Enter Dutchesse, Ferrara, Ursini, Borgia, Cornelia Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: My Lord, you make me wonder, challenge me
Of promises? though I acknowledge it,
No act that could reflect with a dishonour
Upon our person, yet we must not be
So jested into marriage, you are a Prince
Of an unquestioned merit, take not these
Imaginary ways to advance your hopes
In us, we are yet free as you my Lord,
And shall not in a dream give up ourself,
Were we disposed to marry or contract
Ourself, the day shall witness it without
A blush, let guilty souls call night to cover
Their promises, we are innocent.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Good Madam
Render me not so lost to my own senses,
To the honour of a Prince basely to coin
A language for my purpose, though you may
Repent the last nights freedom, and correct
Your judgment of me, make me not so miserable
To let the Court think I invented this
As destitute of nobler ways to move you,
But I presume this is to try my patience
And make my joys at last more precious
By this delay; I know you are all vertue
And cannot stain yourself by a denial
Of any syllable you speak.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: With pardon
Of your grace, I shall laugh if you persist thus:
You had a pleasant dream, but lovers
Are flattered in their sleep, I speak to you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Then Madam I take leave, to tell you it is not
Done like a Princess of that character
We have received, and if I had no witness
I see what mirth we are prepared for.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: There is too much at stake my Lord already,
To rack this argument for your own fame,
Proceed not to enlarge it, we would rather
Confess some guilt against ourself, then let
You honour be exposed to such strait censure
For loving us, yet if you would be silent
In this we shall be proud, in other things
To have denied you nothing, and be ashamed
You took our Court so unprepared to honour you.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Was ever such a mockery, I see
I must produce more testimony, you see
Can justify if you please, I have affirmed
Nothing but truth, although my willing ear
Catched up the voice, she spake it to you signior.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: What my good Lord?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: That she resolved to marry us.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your excellence
Must pardon me, I heard her highness speak
No language to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: We honour
You Borgia for acquitting us.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: It is truth her highness never spake so, but I did
Whom supposed the Duchess, and this must
Sound hope in him to be so negative.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: It seems you have concluded, Madam, I
Must be the general mirth.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I find Cornelias
Cunning in this, and must apply some complement
For our own honour, good my Lord your privacy.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: However her grace be a little impudent
I had been mad to justify the Duke
In such a cause, she has no mind to marry him,
And perhaps talked to me last night to try
My strength of wit, women are subtle creatures,
No matter though Ursini court my sister,
My ambitions fair on the other side again.

div1.stage: Enter Iulio, and Lucio, and whisper with the Dutchesse.

sp.speaker: Vrs.
sp.l: It is strange the Duchess should so mistake.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My conscience she heard the words.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Yet She denies.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I must believe her too:

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: You speak a riddle Madam.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Will you my Lord
Admit of so much mirth.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You shall command me.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Remit them then, the rest I will clear hereafter
To your satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: do ye hear, what Princedo ye mean to call yourself?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Why any Prince in Spain.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: No I will advise you
You shall be an Italian Prince in Spanish habit,
Now I think better on it, it is quaint, and will
Be grateful for the witty novelty:
Every common Prince goes in his countries fashion;
Such as you are not ordinary, be bold.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Why didst bring him hither?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Peace I may do you a courtesy,
Keep your own counsel and be ignorant
Of this strange Creature, say you are---
The Duke of---thus disguised for reasons
Known to yourself.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Duke of---let me alone.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: And be not beaten out of it.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I will not, let the high German first present me in a speech,
Is that the Duchess? so, so.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: My master or his ghost?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: You would not be a fool and lose yourself,
And heaven knows what; scorn to take notice on him,
Remember who you are.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Vmp, umph, stand by fellow.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: Duchess of Urbin, never was your Court
Graced with the presence of so brave a Prince
As this, the darling and delight of Christendom.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: He seems no less.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: What pageants have we got.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: And cozen not yourselves he is no Spaniard.
But of Italian sprightly breed, a man
Famous in Arts and Arms, as shall appear
If any man dares question him, should your grace
But see him at some royal exercise
You would think him more than mortal, he shall pitch
The Bar with any of your Guard, or drink with them;
Wrestle with both the West and North Olympics,
Sings like the Arabian Bird, and can out-dance.
The nimble Elephant, so rarely skilled
In music, that he has a great ambition
To go to hell to challenge Herpes
To play with him, on any Instrument
From the Organ to the Jew's-trump.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Miracles!

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: These are the outside of his qualities,
But look within him, and your grace shall find
Enough to ravish you.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Tell how I love her.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: With all these virtues and advantages
Of blood and state he comes to court your highness.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: We are infinitely honoured, and would thank him,
But that we know not yet this Princes name.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: Duke of Ferrara, Madam, is his title.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: How sirrah?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: That is the Duke of Ferrara, what do ye mean?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Stand to it and say he is a counterfeit
A mere impostor, be not beaten out of it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Are you Duke of Ferrara sirrah, ha.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I am Duke of all the world; what is that to thee?
High German stand close to me.

sp.speaker: As.
sp.l: A true Prince needs no buckler.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Sirrah darest usurp my name?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: It is mine, thou art a counterfeit,
I hope your grace will know me another time.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: A base affront my Lord, and suspect
A plot of Borgias to dishonour you,
He durst not stay to face it.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I will have his heart,
As for this wretch.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Do, do, I looked for this, a true Prince can bear.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Madam you have not used me well.
I say no more.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Let him go madam, I will call him to account hereafter.

sp.speaker: Dut.
