sp.l: We are displeased, hence with that fool and whip him.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: You must be whipped and stripped my scurvy Don.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Whip a Prince? what do ye mean?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: You must be Duke of Ferrara.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Duke of a Fiddlestick, you do not mean, to let me
Catch an Ague Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: The lash when the fit comes will keep you warm, do you know one Pimponio, he was a footman, you will be in case to overtake him presently,he has the heels on you, and you cannot give him so much weight, now you are light, stay but a little we will send you a whip.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: How am I transformed, Duke of Ferrara quotha, would I were anything, I know not what I am as they have handled me.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Is the Duke gone?

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Yes Madam.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I will have the fool hanged then.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: That is I.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Alas poor fellow, ha, ha, ha, what art thou?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Nothing, I hope she does not know me again, I must deny myself.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Come hither Sirrah,
Whose devise was it to bid you say you were
Duke of Ferrara?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Alas not I Madam, he is gone.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Who is gone?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: The insolent fellow that made a fool of your highness.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Whether is he gone?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: To obey your grace and be whipped.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Why do you shake so?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: I am very warm and please your grace.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Where be your clothes?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: My clothes? I never wore any more in my life, I sweat with these.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: He has punishment enough, who waits?
Bid Borgia attend us.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: I shall Madam.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: How now sirrah, what are you?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: A Tumbler, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: I know thee?

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: What not Pimp. honest Pimponio.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Signior Borgia her grace calls for you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I attend.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: How signior Borgia? then I am not I, and there is no Staying here to find myself, as I remember some friends of mine, did promise me a comfortable whip, I will rather venture a cold than stay for it, I must be Dukified, be persuaded into kickes---they will return, I would not tempt my destiny, she promised to hang me, and I can do that for myself when I have a mind to it.

sp.speaker: Ju.
sp.l: Kick that fellow out of the Court.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.p: You are mistaken Sir, he means somebody else, I have been kicked already.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Madam you let fall.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Let it reward your pains.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: Observed you that.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Convey this to Mercutio, it creates him
Controller of our household, this I hope
Will merit more of his acquaintance with
Our Court.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You honour your poor creatures.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Leave us,
You may stay Sir, what suite, what that you named?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Suite Madam?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Did not you say you had a suite to us,
I hope your modesty will teach you how
To limit your request, that it may be
Such as may both become our grant and your
Acceptance, speak what is it.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: My suite Madam?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: But in the confidence of your discretion
Name and enjoy what you desire.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: This bounty
Of language is beyond all my ambition.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Well Sir to the purpose, I would have you speak
To purpose now.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To purpose, would I durst,
This exceeds all the rest, shall I be mad
And lose this opportunity.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: We are prepared

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Better? my happiness flows upon me
My suite is Madam, you would be pleased to---
What shall I say, she looks so keen and tempting,
I have a great mind to kiss her.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Not resolved yet?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Long since, my humble suite is to you Madam, that---

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: I may be numbered still among your creatures
And keep a blessing in your gracious smiles
Upon my humble service.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: A smile and humblest service, is this all?
You will not purchase much by being a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: The greatest rise by favour, I have lost
An opportunity.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Is there nothing else?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She Asks again, now I will put her toot,
We are private, I have another suite Madam.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: A courtier should have many, what is it made on?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Of love.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: A pretty winter wearing, and keeps well
In fashion.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: May I presume to as ask your grace.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: A question? yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Do you love me Madam?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Does your grace love me?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Audacious Groom, how dares thy soul imagine
So great an impudence, almost treason to us,
Are all our favours thought so cheap? and we
Considered in the crowd of other women
Fit for your mixture, to be stained with loose
And desperate proffers of your wanton service?
Have we no more distinction in our birth
And titles? Or do ye hope we are disarmed
Of strength to punish such an insolence?
Had smiles taken such possession of our brow
Thou couldst expect no killing frown for this?
Was our eye grown so tame nothing could quicken it
Into a flame, into a consuming lightning,
When such an object durst appear to vex it?
Thus we could spurn thy saucy head off---but
We pardon it, do ye hear? we freely pardon it,
To show mercy is above all fault,
And that we are at home Queen of our passions,
Nor shall you suffer under the remembrance,
It is now as it had never been, and you keep
The first place in our thoughts.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Wisely preserve them
And rather chide your timorous understanding
Than think us angry, had your sin been greater
We should have met it charitably, come,
You are our Secretary, write as we shall dictate.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Did ever Sunshine break so suddenly
From such a black and most prodigious cloud?
I would have sold my body for a bean stalk
Within two minutes, she has an excellent wit
And cunningly she reins it, what is your pleasure
I shall write Madam?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: A letter, a love letter, are you ready,
Write as I bid upon your life,---I love you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I am prepared.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Write I love you Sir, do ye not understand me?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She will make me mad, I have done, I love you.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: There wanted Sir, I love you Sir.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: And if you be not short of apprehension.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: And if, etc.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: You will wisely entertain it.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You will wisely, etc.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: All errors be forgot, meet me this evening

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: All errors, etc.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: In the privy Garden, and receive more testimony.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: In the privy garden, etc.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Mean time here is my hand, that in the morning I will marry you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Mean time, etc.---What a devil does she mean?
I have done, it wants your confirmation---so.
To whom shall I direct it?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: You will be trusty, there is danger else.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To whom?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: To him that loves me best,
Deceive me not farewell.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I love you Sir, etc. it is a letter, and I wrote it,
To whom, to him that loves her best, if none love her better,
It is to myself? Why am I so scrupulous?
She has made me Chancellor in the cause,
There is no particular named, yet she was angry,
Yet she was pleased again, and had my crime
Been greater, she had met it charitably.
Come I perceive the whole device as sure
As I have any sense, she does affect me,
And tries me at the last weapon of wit
How I will behave myself, are you there Duchess;
She is my own, and this invites me to
The close of all my happiness, if I
Forfeit this opportunity, let Midas
Transplant his goodly ears to this dull head,
And let all women laugh at me, my stars
I bow to you, and kiss your influence,
I am exalted to your sphere already,
Where, with the Duchess I will fit and shine
A constellation.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You are well met Sir,
Borgia I take it.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: You may change that name
And call me servant.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You have prostrate language,
But carry treason in your heart, you know me?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Duke of Ferrara.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: So, was it your plot to bring
That puppet to affront me before the Duchess?
Was there no other name to be usurped,
Dishonoured, and profaned by hounds and monkeys
But mine?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I understand you not, your anger
Is not directed right my Lord, I am not
Guilty in thought.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Your fears shall not excuse.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: You are abused.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: I know I am Sir, and
Will print revenge upon your heart, it shall carry
The character of a villain.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I must tell you Duke.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Were you master of the world,
Could you shoot death beyond a Basilisk,
Or had you mischief in your breath above
The Lernean vapours, or the killing steam
Of the hot lake that poisons innocent Birds
But daring to fly over, I would rise
With as much confidence to scorn this calumny
As I would quench my thirst, or chide my Groom
The drudges for me, Duke I am no villain,
And though my blood runs not so deep a purple
There is no corruption in the cheapest vein
My Liver feeds, it is clear and honest sir,
In thy own Court I will meet and tell thee so
Maugre thy guards, and gaudy Butter-flies,
I dare, by innocence, I dare.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: You think
The place protects you now.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Were it in a Church
No drop of mine could stain it, Duke I cannot
Fear and be master of a sword, that needs
No valour in a cause so just as mine
To stir the point, by all my hopes.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Thy hopes,
Of what reversion? what Groom's place is vacant?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Come it is not done becomingly
To insult because you have a privilege
Of Duke above you, I am here a servant
To a most gracious Princess.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: At that name I drew
New flame, and should I credit thy soul free
From this dishonour, thou hast sin enough
In thy ambition to pull ruin on thee,
Are we too fit to be in competition Sir?
Hast thou a thought so proud, so daring in thee
To be my rival? Have I courted her
To her own height, a Prince? and shall her vassal
Look on her with an eye, less than serves
The Altar with, because she is pleased some time
To laugh, and seem indulgent to your services
For her own sake, can you have brain to think
Such treason to her judgment, that she loves you?
Or can she be so lost to truth and honour
Not to make good her promises to me
Religious as a contract, has she not
Declared me worthy of her, and my love
The best of all the world.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: How was that Sir?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The best of all the world, it is not that I
Can be so poor in my esteem of her
Whose mention is sacred, or myself
That I have any jealousy thou canst
Inherit possibly the hundredth part
Of any thought that points upon affection
Hast thou no soul to apprehend thy scorn?
Nay did she not, fearing thou mightst grow insolent
Upon her favours late declare herself,
It was not love but mirth and wantonness
Of revelling nights, commanding on thy life
Thou feed no ambition higher, or feed a thought
To her, beyond what waited upon duty
You may remember this.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: It is clear, this none
Could tell him but herself, I find too plain
Who is the may-game of the Court, this last
Convinces me, your pardon mighty Sir
You love the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Best she will acknowledge
Of all mankind.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I have a letter to you,
I will not doubt my pardon when you read it,
It is to you Sir if there can be a joy beyond what is there contained

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Ha? I am blest,
Borgia let me embrace thee my best friend
Dwell in my heart, divide with me Ferrara
Or Urbin, anything but the Duchess, say
I will meet her in the Garden were it walled
With flaming Dragons, I have not a soul
Spacious enough to entertain this happiness
Beyond my hope, above my life dear Borgia.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Beyond his hope? it seems this joy was not
Expected umph, and I had no commission
To give it him, after all this if she
Meant it not this way, I have made fine work,
She might have named him, would I had the paper
Again, now do I prophesy I have
Undone myself, and only her grace meant
That I should meet her, curse upon my easiness;
I have lost an opportunity, no fate
Flattered a mortal with the like, dull brains,
There is yet prevention, genius I thank thee,
It is possible I may secure the Garden
And boldly meet her first, if any destiny
Owe me this blessing with this art I may
Redeem my folly, never man but I
Would lose so rich an opportunity.

div1.stage:
Ectus Quintus.
Enter Dutchesse, Mercutio, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Madam I know not what to say, my heart
Is full of hearty zeal to obey you, but the place
You have conferred upon my years, is much
Above my strength to satisfy, yet I thank you.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: You have deserved we should encourage you
For what is past, your son is full of hope
And may grow up a statesman.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He owes all
To your infinite favours Madam, a young man,
And would be active upon your commands.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Leave us, stay my Lord we must employ you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I have not life enough to serve you Madam
My age is now a burthen, that I could
Shake off a score of winters.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: There is no such
Necessity of youth to execute
The service you design, you love your son.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Above my own health Madam, and let me
Be bold to tell your grace, I love him better
For your sake.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: For our sake.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That he can carry
Himself so handsomely to deserve your good
Opinion, every Courtier that is advanced
To a warm place, does not behave himself
Always to purpose.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: To what purpose Signior?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: To please his Mistress, and I am, I must
Confess proud of his expectations,
It makes my blood dance Madam.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: You are very merry.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I hope to have more cause.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Well Sir, while we
Retire into the Garden, be it your care
We be not interrupted, give access
To none but Borgia , we have some privacies
Only concern his knowledge.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My son Borgia.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Your son, if you do call him Borgia.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Shall I go for him?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: He will be so officious
Perhaps to spare that trouble, if he come
Be diligent and admit him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I shall Madam;
She is gone into the Garden, and commands
I give access to none but Borgia ;
If he come, she has given me another office
To keep the door, it has been a preferment.
I will do it now in spite of my own humour,
Ha boy! something will come of it, if he have
The grace to nick this opportunity.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The evening wastes a pace, I cannot be
Too soon at my desires, who that?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He is come;
Already Borgia.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: One stands Sentinel,
Is that the word? who names Borgia.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My son.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: The same.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: This evening make thee happy, enter, no ceremony
I am not now against thy being a Duke,
Prove fortunate my boy, and bless thy father.
So, so, if it were no-one, and the Sun looked
With his broad brightest eye upon us, there are
Convenient cozening Arbours, cost bestowed
On pretty mazes, labyrinths of love;
You might be there secure, and entertain
Sweet time, most tall and fashionable hedges
In whose enclosures, Ladies that are willing
May lose themselves, and the next walk no wiser;
Now I think on it, this Cloister with the help
Of such an evening might be dark enough
For such a turn; many a gentlewoman
Has been content to embrace upon worse terms
O the Court lobbies, but I tell no tales,
Another moving this way, by his favour
The Gardens taken up.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: It is the best way
To say I am the Duke, that if he follow
He may prevent his own access.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Umph, umph.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: That name will make the gates fly open to me
And I pass undiscovered.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What are you?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Here do thy office, I am the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The Duke
Your grace must pardon me, I am commanded
To admit none, her highness will enjoy
The garden privately.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Lord Mercutio.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your servant, but in this my duty must
Aim at another's pleasure, if you be
The Duke I cannot help it, I am but
Green in my honours, and I would not forfeit them
With my own head to boot in her first service.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Then I will discover I am Borgia
Your son, your happy Borgia, be not you
The enemy, and bar my glorious fortune,
The Duchess has commanded me this evening
To meet her in the Garden, I can tell
Thee wonders old Mercutio , she loves me,
More I have an assurance from her hand
She will make me Duke old lad.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Be not transported
For if you be my son do you observe
You are yet but Borgia, and I your father
Old Mercutio, and old lad.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your pardon Sir,
My joy of such a bliss allows no bound,
Why are you slow to make your son the happiest
Of all mankind, the evenings big with glory
The winds do whisper gently whose I am,
The birds with Music wait to entertain me
Into Loves Bower, the Trees bow to my entrance,
And she that is the Mistress of all these
Will bid me welcome.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Are you Borgia.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: There is death in these delays, do not you know me?
Or dare you not believe what I affirm
Touching the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I believe you are
Borgia to my grief, and do believe
What you have said; her grace did appoint me
To wait here, and commanded I should give
Access to none but Borgia, do ye mark?
She was pleased to tell me, she had business only
Concerned your knowledge, I dispute not what,
But it is some excellent affair I am confident,
She was so merry about the lips and eyes
And praised you to my face.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: If this have faith with ye
Why am not I admitted?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: All in good time.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: The gates should spread themselves.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: They shall not need, I will teach them with less trouble,
But first I have a suite to you.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: To me,
Speak and command it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: It is within man's remembrance
That you did want a pardon, now beg mine,
And make what other conditions with the Duchess
You please.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Your pardon?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes I am parcel Traitor
Against my will, and too much care above
My office made me abuse it, I admitted
Another gentleman, that deceived me with
Your name, and how her grace may punish me
Is in my fears, unless you mediate for me.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Did any take my name.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, and at first
Sound I discharged my duty the wrong way
And let him in.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: In? whether?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Into the Duchess.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I am undone, this minute, I am blasted;
It was the Duke upon my life.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The Duke, it may be so, although it were duskish
Methought he carried more compass with him;
But why should he take your name?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You found I had no zeal to his, how ever
Lose no more time; your power with her grace
May set all straight, and purchase me a pardon.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Be rather lost as I am in thy dotage,
Thou hast deprived me of the wealthiest harvest
That ever Sunbeams shined on.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Does he thou me?
How would he domineer and he were Duke?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: My fortune bleeds to death, it is now too late
That paper ruins all my hope, and were
We equal, she would scorn my want of confidence
And laugh me out of the world.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He is very passionate.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: But there is no dwelling in this Wilderness,
Things past are past sorrow, there is yet
A way to bind my wound up and secure
My health, though not a life with so much state
As was expected, instantly I will to
Cornelia , I know she loves me still,
At worst a little passion bestowed
On her, with clearing I am another brother
Makes her my own, and keeps me from the Pasquil;
I shall be jeered to dust else, there is my rest,
He that loves more than one is seldom blest.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He is gone and I am like to suffer for it,
By your highness favour I will wait no longer
To be chastised, but when your grace is weary,
You shall not need to strike me at the door;
It is open and I vanish in the dark;
Stay and I will send some others to attend you,
You will want light, my son shall be no Duke
I perceive now, nor will I be a Courtier;
Put me to keep the door?

div1.stage:
Exit.
Enter Cornelia, Laura, and Melinda.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Did she dismiss you then?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: It was not her pleasure
We should attend.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: We left my Lord Mercutio
Your father with her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Went she towards the Garden?

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: Yes, where is your brother Borgia?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I know not.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: He is infinitely beholding to her grace,
She never mentions him without a flourish:
I know not, but if I have any skill
In looks or language, there is something more
Than common in her highness breast meant toward him

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: She may be in love.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: In love with whom?

sp.speaker: Laus
sp.l: Your brother.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I blush to hear your weakness, I hope he
Hath more wit than to build vain hopes on that;
Eagles stoop not to flies.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: But the Wren
Couched underneath the aspiring Eagles wings.
Quickly advance itself when the other is mounted
And glories in her hight, it is but a step
And the small thing is King of birds, the fable
Has pretty morals in it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I am not sure
A rebel in my nature to his fortune,
But dare not pawn my own discretion
To take up your opinions.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Signior Pisauro your brothers friend desires
To speak with you.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: We will leave you Madam, by this time her grace
May want our duties.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Did I fright you Ladies, look better on me.

sp.speaker: Lau.
sp.l: We have seen you round Sir.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: But do not know what is in me.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.l: We desire
To die in that precious ignorance.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: This Lady I hope is not of your mind.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Your pleasure
My servant says you would speak with me?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: If you
Remember Lady I was bold to urge
A little counsel on you, how it fastens
I come to understand.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What counsel Sir.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: About your brother Signior Borgia.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Please you assist my memory.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Why it was
But this, I had a kind of fear you loved
This brother Madam.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Would you have me be
So impious not to affect my brother.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: But you loved him the wrong way, do ye hear lustily
You understand, with the desire of coupling:
There lies no dispensation for that lock,
It is impious and abominable, you had better
In the state you are in keep a Pensioner
To give you heats, a fellow that will venture
His body at all hours; then to offend once
With so much sin to nature.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Do you think
I am a Monster Signior?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Better marry
An honest man and make one a great deal:
Your husband may be excused in the progress Lady,
Besides he may have faults, a negligence
In his visits, or mistaking of his times,
When you are invited by another Lord
To a banquet, or take physic, or the air
Appointed by your Doctor, there are reasons
To excuse an active Lady that is married
But to affect your brother so, inexpiable.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You have invention enough to furnish
The Court with vice, how ever you seem to have
Care of my soul, pray give me pardon Sir,
Do you ever mean to marry?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Marry? O yes.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Not a Court Lady sure.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: One of that tribe to choose.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Without the fear
Of being such a monster made by her
Whose wantonness you wittily have charactered.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I have read my destiny, she that I shall marry
Will be very honest, exceeding chaste as I
Shall be to her, I did but tell you what
Whirligigs are in the world, and that it were better
And safer for your conscience to be one
Of Venus order, and keep tame a Groom
A stallion Dormant than embrace a brother.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What should incline you
To imagine me so lost to modesty?
What have you read in me to make you think
I love my brother so?

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: My charity.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: There is little charity in those suspicions.
Have you no other argument.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Your brother
Told me himself you loved him strangely.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: So, so.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Nay, nay he was in the same pickle.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He told
You that himself too.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Yes, yes, till I tampered with him
And sacrificed his flesh with ghostly counsel,
Read Law and Lectures, I will tell you Madam
He was once so overgrown with love, he had
Resolved to tell you he was not your brother,
And rather than be frustrate of his hopes
Vowed to forswear it, and suborn testimony
He was no kin to you, born I know not where,
And never saw the town afore, whose people
Had all this while cozened themselves, with an
Opinion he was Borgia; here is a youth now,
Did he never deal with you to such a purpose.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Never, he would not be so wicked sure.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Did you ever hear the like? you know it now,
Thank heaven and a good friend that told you this;
A friend that would not see this pretty vessel
Lost in the quick-sands, when both goods and it
May be his own another day: I love you
And none shall do you wrong.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I should be ingrateful
Not to acknowledge Sir this noble office
Meant to preserve me.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: That was my pure meaning,
You may requite it if you please.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: With love.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: It is the reward my ambition first aims at.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I love my brother now in his own place,
And being his bosom friend I will not question,
But to enlarge my knowledge of your worth
And take me nearer to me for his Character,
And free consent.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Umph, now you bless me Lady,
If his hopes thrive in the Duchess as I doubt not
I am made, I will seek him out, I wish no better
Testimony, he shall not gilt you under his hand.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: No haste.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: He knows me to a thought, nay, nay
He shall do it presently, if I can light on him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Tomorrow Signior, I suspect it not.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: It does concern my honour, it is done instantly,
She may be cold ere morning, I will not lose
This opportunity, I am made for ever.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He has an odd way of Courtship, sure my brother,
Unless he know him better than this wildness
Can promise, will be sparing to contract
Our hearts too fast, he has but a rough outside,
But my strange thoughts within me are corrected,
And I possess myself again thank providence,
Ursini.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Madam I am bold to press
On your retirement, but when you remember
I bring no mutinous thoughts, but such as are
Devoted to your service, you will think it
A trespass that may soon invite a pardon.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You must first practise to offend my Lord,
This is favour to me.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Still such goodness
Flows from your language to me at the first
Encounter; but when I take boldness to
Have some assurance from you alone,
Which I have hoped and served for, with the truth
Of your best honourer, you decline the subject,
Or fly the sweet conclusion.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My Lord,
That you have loved, at least professed so much,
May easily be granted, but let me
Beseech you Sir, did you upon the first
Motion that wrought upon your mind to think
Me worthy of your love acquaint me with it.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: No Madam,
I long cherished the soft fire
That tried the pureness of it, and the object
Thatshot so bright a flame into my bosom,
And had suppressed it still, but that your vertue
Grew up too powerful against it, then
I took leave to express how much I wished
To be your votary.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Give me equal licence
My Lord in the same cause to try myself,
I have thoughts too would be composed of something
In you to be examined.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: I submit,
And shall obey your censure, life and death
Hang on your lip, I come to be determined
Your servant or your sacrifice, for to languish
At distance thus.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Then you expect an answer
Presently, I much fear my Lord I shall not,
In that particular, satisfy your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: You want no knowledge of me, there is nothing
In my past fate but may appear to you;
My nature needs no gloss, my blood, my fortune
Clear to your view, my person not much withered;
If these together want a charm, I can
Deserve you may love, for I know best
The extent of my devotions, and the heart
That though you should despise it must still serve you.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: But good my Lord what answer you to this?
Is it becoming the discretion
Of a noble servant to pursue his mistress
By unruly ways, and interpose commands
And power of great ones to enforce the heart
Of any Lady: though I must confess
Her grace may challenge my obedience
To her law and person, it has been yet a rule,
And love and religion cannot be compelled

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: You do not conclude me, if I obtained
A favour from the Duchess to propound
My wishes, and plead for me, I know well
The soul is not her subject, could her power
Bestow your body on me, and that I
Could boast myself Lord of beauteous frame
Without your mind, I were more tyrant to
Accept than she to force, and answer for
A crime more fatal than the ravishers.

sp.speaker: Pie.
sp.l: Your brother Madam.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: If I have any power
My Lord you must not leave me, yet I would
Entreat your small retreat behind the hangings
For a few minutes.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Your command is a favour.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: O Cornelia.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What is the matter brother.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Are you alone.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You see my company.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Do ye love me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Love you brother, what have I
Done to beget your doubt.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: But do you love me
More than a sister? if I were not Borgia ,
Remove from us the common tie of blood
Which is not love, but forced of nature in us,
Could you affect me then, then if I answered
This honour with a true and noble flame
Upon such brave conditions, Cornelia
Could our hearts meet and marry?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: This were strange,
But not so strange that we should love.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Then pardon
Fairest Cornelia, and make him blest
Whose very soul dotes on thee, I have but
Usurped the name of Borgia , I can give
Thee proof.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: It is come about.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Pisauro welcome
The man of all mankind, most wished for welcome:
Madam this gentleman can witness I am
None of your brother, we were bred together,
Both born in Millan, and my name is
Aurelio Androzzi son to Paulo
Androzzi major domo to the Dukedom,
My friend too of a noble family.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Did not I tell you this.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Weary of home
We both engaged ourselves to try our fortune
Abroad, and for the wars had last designed
Ourselves, we took but Urbin in the way,
Where some good stars detained us, and I taken
For Borgia pursued thus far the story.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Do ye laugh at me, Pisauro she is incredulous.
Speak and convince her with thy testimony.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I have told enough already.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: She wants faith.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: That gentleman prepared me for this history
Do you not blush brother? Sir I thank you.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I am sorry for his impudence.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: Cornelia,
Pisauro Why art thou silent.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: I tell you I did speak to her.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: It is time I then dispose myself.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Now my happiness.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My Lord I pray come forth.
You Gentlemen by your own confessions
Are strangers to me, and although I do not
Distrust heavens providence, I shall not sin
To give my freedom up where I am known;
My Lord if you accept Cornelia
She is thus confirmed your own.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: With greater joy
Than I would take an Empire, this drops peace
Upon my brothers ashes, and unites
For ever our two families.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Where is the Duchess?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I prithee do not vex me.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Do not vex
Thyself, come we are at large, our constitution
Would have been troubled with a wife, we have
The world before us, store of game is necessary,
The Duchess.

div1.stage: Enter Dutchesse, Ferrara, Pietro, Iulio, Lucio Laura Melinda.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: You now possess us freely, the next morning
Shall spread this joy through Urbin.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: We are happy
And every heart congratulates.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: We thank you
Signior Ursini, you have been faithful to us.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Is your name Borgia?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: No Madam,

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Where is our letter?
We did not think you had been so apprehensive,
You see it now confirmed, we hope you had
No thought we meant it otherwise, be prudent
And careful in your province, heaven I see
Would have it thus, and rectify our folly.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your pardon gracious Madam.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Signior,
We thank your diligence, possess our favour.
And know the Duke.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am one of the worst keepers of a door,

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: No more, all is well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am glad of it.

sp.speaker: Urs.
sp.l: Sir your blessing.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Madam your smiles upon us and we cannot
Despair of happiness.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But where is Borgia?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: I know not Sir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: Rise ever fortunate.

sp.p: Oyez, oyez.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.l: A fool has lost his master, and thus cries him
About the Court.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Pimponio on my conscience.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Oyez;
If any man there be
In town or in country
Can tell me of a wight
Was lost but yesternight,
His name was I know
Signior Aurelio ,
By these marks he is known,
He had a bush of his own,
Two eyes in their place
And a nose on his face,
His beard is very thin
But no hair on his chin,
Bring word to the crier
His desolate squire,
And for this fine feat
Take what you can get;
And heaven bless Pimponio , for nobody knows me
And I know nobody else to pray for.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He is not my brother indeed then.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nor my son.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: It is too true Madam, here, here is thy master

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: No, no, that is Signior Borgia, do not deceive yourself

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: We are both deceived Pimponio shall I hope
Of your free pardon Madam for all trespasses?
My Lord your breath is powerful.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Rise Aurelio.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.l: And be dear to us.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I hope the pardon is firm.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Irrevocable.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I will dispatch letters then to Naples, thence
He did salute me last, how were we cozened!
But Sir I thank you for my Borgias pardon.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Although it be clear now you are not my brother
Pray take my poor acknowledgement, I shall
Be proud for your sake, to preserve your friendship.

sp.speaker: Bor.
sp.l: May your hopes prosper in him; now we two
With licence of your excellence may
Prosecute our design again for the wars.

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: If nothing else at Court invite your stay
We lay commands upon you as our servant
That you see all our ceremonies finished,
To celebrate this happy union
You must be both our guests.

sp.speaker: Pim.
sp.l: Do let us feast
And fortify ourselves, we shall have
Our bellies full of fighting time enough.

sp.speaker: Pis.
sp.l: Thinks your grace so?

sp.speaker: Dut.
sp.l: Subjects may love as their rude sense imparts,
But heaven doth only govern Princes hearts.
